DOC.HEAD: Army Reserves Looking For Panama Volunteers; Get Many
DOC.TEXT: The Army has been flooded with offers from volunteers who want to go to Panama and help restore battered public services, a spokesman said Wednesday. ``It's unbelievable,'' said Maj. Henry Fitts, a spokesman at the U.S. Army Reserve Special Operations Command at Fort Bragg, N.C. ``Call it patriotism, call it boredom, call it what you will, but we've had to set up a 24-hour operation just to screen the volunteers,'' Fitts said. The Pentagon already has dispatched 25 reserve civil affairs specialists along with 107 active duty experts to Panama. Civil affairs specialists act as liaison officers between the military and the civilian government to help re-establish public services disrupted by fighting, such as utilities and transportation. Virtually all the Army's civil affairs specialists are in reserve units, and the Pentagon paged those units for volunteers, Fitts said. ``We've (in the reserves) been requested by the (regular) Special Operations Command to augment the active duty civil affairs officers in their effort to rebuild and restore order in Panama,'' he said. The Army particularly sought specialists, such as engineers or people familiar with transit systems or sanitation programs. So many have volunteered, Fitts said in a telephone interview, that he's been unable to get a count. The number to be chosen to go to Panama probably will be ``in the dozens, rather than hundreds, because we really need people with specific talents,'' he said. Most people can be expected to put in about two weeks, but regulations permit a tour of duty of up to 139 days, a bit less than 20 weeks. In Florida, soldiers from the 361st Civil Affairs Bridgade in Pensacola and a subordinate unit, the 478th Civil Affairs Company in Perrine, near Miami, will leave Friday for Panama, said Maj. Tom Bechtell, a member of the brigade. Lt. Col. Richard Randall, plans and operations officer of the brigade, said his unit will ``help the government with certain expertise our individuals have in banking, utilities, medical (matters), public transportation, law enforcement and education.'' The 361st trains in Panama every year and routinely works with the civil government and U.S. military there, Randall said. About 25 percent of the Pensacola-based reservists and half of those in Perrine speak Spanish, he said.
